nodes.text: A face recognition system based on Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and the eigenface approach can be implemented to effectively recognize human faces
PCA reduces dimensionality by representing each training image as a linear combination of eigenvectors (eigenfaces) computed from the covariance matrix of the training set
Recognition is performed by projecting a test image onto the eigenface subspace and classifying by minimum Euclidean distance between weight vectors

The eigenface algorithm computes the mean face, subtracts it from training images, computes a reduced MxM matrix of inner products to obtain M largest eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and then constructs K eigenfaces corresponding to the largest eigenvalues
Training images are vectorized (size MxN to MNx1), centered to same size and alignment, and assembled into a training set S (example used: 34 images of size 200x149)

Compute average face vector, subtract it from each training vector to form matrix A, compute covariance-related matrix L = A^T A (MxM) to efficiently obtain principal eigenvectors, then form eigenfaces from these

Project training and test images onto the K-dimensional eigenface space to obtain weight vectors; classification uses Euclidean distance between test weight vector and training weight vectors, nearest minimum indicates identity
The system can optionally update eigenfaces or add characteristic weight patterns when unknown faces are repeatedly observed
Implementation used MATLAB and an image database from ETE-07 series, RUET (example: 36 images of 18 persons; earlier text mentions 34 training images of 200x149 pixels)
Experimental tests included images with same pose and with pose variation; results showed recognition of individual images in both same-pose and some pose-variation cases
The eigenface-based system performed well on Bitmap, PNG and JPEG images and gave very good classification of faces under constrained conditions

Limitations include sensitivity to variations in image size and constrained environment assumptions (images should be near-frontal, centered and same size); significant variations in size remain a problem

Future work plans include extending the system to real-time video-based recognition, using larger databases, addressing varying image sizes, and comparing PCA performance with other face recognition methods
